title-group.article-title: Enhancing the originality of the Stewart platform through its kinematic analyses

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Instituto Tecnológico de Celaya, México

author-notes.corresp: Jaime Gallardo-Alvarado, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Instituto Tecnológico de Celaya, Av. Tecnológico y A. García Cubas, 38010 Celaya, GTO, México. Email: jaime.gallardo@itcelaya.edu.mx, gjaime@itc.mx

abstract.p: In this study, an approach to solve the kinematics of the Stewart platform is introduced with the purpose to enhance its originality. Contrary to the Gough platform, the forward displacement analysis of the Stewart platform is based on closure equations that allow to obtain nearly closed-form solutions. These equations lead to decoupled functions which are solved by means of the well-known Sylvester's dialytic method of elimination. The input–output equations of velocity and acceleration as well as the singularities of the robot are obtained systematically by resorting to reciprocal-screw theory. Numerical examples are provided in order to demonstrate the application of the proposed method. Furthermore, the numerical results obtained via screw theory are successfully compared with simulations generated with the aid of commercially available software. Finally, the contribution may be useful to recognize that the flight simulator proposed by Stewart almost five decades ago and the tire testing machine attributed to Gough are in reality robot manipulators with quite different characteristics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Flight simulators date back to 1909 when the Antoinette Barrel Trainer was designed by a French company to help pilots to control motion wheels before the aircraft was flown; it is noticeable that by that time airplane accidents were unfortunately a frequent occurrence. To the best knowledge of the author, the first person killed in a powered fixed-wing aircraft was a US Army lieutenant, where the pilot had been the famous Orville Wright. Furthermore, by the time World War I came around, Germany had lost more than 70 pilots. Without doubt, World War I was an imperative motive for the development of efficient flight simulators. This interest evidently grew during World War II. In the mid-1960s Stewart, working for the Space and Weapons Research Establishment on aviation simulation at the Elliott Automation Company, published the nowadays most celebrated theoretical paper devoted to the study of parallel manipulators entitled ‘A platform with six degrees of freedom’.1,2 Stewart's paper was the motive of ardent communications which were published in the same proceedings. In that concern, the originality of the Stewart platform was severely questioned. Gough, the person who built the first octahedral hexapod, claimed that the Stewart platform was very similar to the universal machine designed by himself with the purpose to determine the properties of tires under the action of combined loads.3,4 In that way, Fichter et al.5 published a retrospective appreciation of the contributions of Gough and Stewart including reprints of those pioneering papers as well as the communications offered by engineers and scientists about the flight simulator of Stewart. Furthermore, Bonev6 reported a well-documented study with the purpose to elucidate the true origins of parallel manipulators. Based on the evidences presented by Fichter et al.5 and Bonev,6 it seems that some well-known developments related with parallel kinematic machines are not properly credited or have been incorrectly classified.

In this study, a simple method to solve the kinematics of the original Stewart platform is introduced. The remainder of the contribution is organized as follows. In `A controversial six-degrees-of-freedom robot manipulator' section, the relevant communications raised by Stewart's paper are discussed. The topology of the Stewart platform is outlined in `Description of the Stewart platform' section. The `Displacement analysis' section of the robot under study is addressed next. The input–output (I/O) equations of velocity and acceleration are established by resorting to reciprocal-screw theory in `Infinitesimal kinematics' section 5. Furthermore, the singularity analysis of the Stewart platform is briefly explained via the I/O equation of velocity. With the purpose to demonstrate the application of the method, `Numerical examples' section which were verified with the aid of commercially available software like ADAMS© are provided. Finally, this contribution may be useful to show that the Stewart platform and the tire testing machine built by Gough are quite different mechanisms at the light of modern kinematics.

sec.title: A controversial six-degrees-of-freedom robot manipulator
sec.p: In 1966, a theoretical paper dealing with a new six-degrees-of-freedom mechanism for simulating flight conditions in the training of pilots was published in the proceedings of the IMechE. This section discusses some of the communications raised by Stewart's1 paper.

It is a common practice to describe the Stewart platform as the tire testing machine credited to Gough, although clearly they are mechanically different. As shown in Figure 1, the Gough platform consists of a moving platform connected by six extendible limbs to the fixed platform through, respectively, spherical and universal joints. On the other hand, in the Stewart platform, the moving platform is connected to the fixed platform by means of only three extendible limbs, and therefore some of the limitations such as complex forward kinematics, limited workspace and poor manipulability of the Gough platform can be ameliorated. Contrary to the Gough platform, the Stewart platform could be classified as a partially decoupled robot.7 Figure 1.
The Gough and Stewart platforms.

The contribution of Stewart1 was the motive of both, praises and hard communications. Consider for instance that Meir offered positive and exhaustive comments about potential applications of the Stewart platform; the elegant mathematical treatment thereof used to approach the kinematic analysis was also well appreciated by Meir. However, the same Meir considered that the inclusion of a computer accompanied by six servo motors could represent a serious obstacle to develop the new parallel manipulator due to the obvious hight cost of such mechatronic system. It is difficult to imagine how a new machine can be cheaper than commercially available options, e.g. nowadays one of the main problems to introduce the general hexapod as a multi-axis machine tool has been the use of spherical joints. However, this has not been a motive to stop the publication of remarkable contributions studying the virtues of parallel manipulators. The mobility analysis of the Stewart platform was commended by Hunt who encouraged Stewart to explore other criteria concerned with the effective computation of the degrees of freedom of the proposed spatial mechanism; all the unstable configurations should be reconsidered according to Hunt. It is noticeable that many mobility formulae have been set in the last 160 years, and none of them is infallible. Furthermore, by the time the computation of the degrees of freedom of mechanisms concerned with practical applications was usually unlooked by engineers. Therefore, the mobility analysis made by Stewart for his invention is a significative effort. Nicholls considered that centrifuge motions cannot be performed by the Stewart platform. Evidently, this is a wrong assumption because the mechanism under judgment is a robot manipulator capable to realize six-degrees-of-freedom. In fact, the moving platform can undergo three rotations plus three translations. Hence, spherical motions are available for the Stewart platform. The mobility of the Stewart platform was also questioned by Thomas who innocently asked, are six degrees of freedom really necessary? With certain sarcasm Stewart simply replied that perhaps Mr. Thomas wanted to know if flight simulations really worth while. More communications followed the theoretical paper of Stewart, and without doubt the most abrasive was the review done by Gough. The originality of the Stewart platform was bitterly disappointed by Gough who claimed that a machine with identical characteristics named tyre test machine3,4 was designed by himself many years before the Stewart platform. It is a little surprising that the same Stewart accepted the commentary of Gough and simply justified the originality of his contribution based on the weak argument that he had been unaware of Gough's invention, although clearly both mechanisms are quite different. Ironically, nowadays six-legged in parallel manipulators are, incorrectly, called Gough–Stewart platforms. There are hundreds of papers describing the Stewart platform as a six-legged six-degrees-of-freedom in parallel manipulator, see for instance.8–11 Furthermore, the situation becomes more confused when Cappel noted that he also invented, in 1961, a flight simulator based on a platform system.12

The purpose of this contribution is not to elucidate who really invented the hexapod. This subject has been clearly exposed in refs,5,6 but to show, through the kinematic analyses, that the Stewart platform is an original invention that was hardly questioned based on weak arguments is one of the main purposes of this study.

sec.title: Description of the Stewart platform
sec.p: In this section, a technical description of the Stewart platform, as well as most of the notation used throughout the contribution, is provided.

The Stewart platform, see Figure 2, is a parallel manipulator composed by a triangular moving platform and a fixed platform connected to each other by means of three extendible limbs. Each limb, here called a double leg, is built with a hydraulic jack (primary limb) whose orientation is constrained by a second jack (secondary limb) attached to the distal end of the first cylinder. In order to describe the geometry of the robot, the reference coordinate system XYZ is selected in such a way that its origin is located at the center O of the fixed platform with the Y-axis normal to the plane of the fixed platform. The geometric centers of the spherical joints, connecting the primary limbs to the moving platform, are denoted by Ci (unless otherwise specified i = 1, 2, 3). These points are located by vectors Ci. The nominal positions of the universal joints, connecting the primary limbs to the fixed platform, are denoted by points Ai = (axi, 0, azi) located by vectors Ai. Furthermore, in a double leg, the primary and secondary limbs are linked with each other through a revolute joint whose nominal position Bi = (Xi, Yi, Zi) is located by vector Bi. On the other hand, the secondary limbs are connected to the fixed platform by means of universal joints whose nominal positions are denoted by points A¯i=(ax¯i,0,az¯i) located by vectors Āi. The distance between the centers of adjacent spherical joint are denoted by dij while ei indicates the distance between points Ai and Bi. In a double leg, the axes of the ith universal joint are denoted by unit vectors ui and vi, where the axis ui is along the line AiĀi while the vector vi, which is also parallel to the axis of the revolute joint in the same double leg, is normal to the plane AiĀiBi. Finally, qi denotes the generalized coordinate associated to the prismatic joint of the ith primary limb, whereas q¯i denotes the generalized coordinate representing the prismatic joint of the secondary limb. Geometry scheme of the Stewart platform.

sec.title: Displacement analysis
sec.p: One of the most challenging problems of robot kinematics is the forward displacement analysis (FDA) of parallel manipulators. Consider for instance that the FDA of the general Gough platform was considered by Freudenstein as the Everest of modern kinematics. In this section, the FDA and inverse displacement analysis (IDA) of the Stewart platform are carried out by resorting to simple closure equations.

The FDA consists of finding the pose, position and orientation, of the triangular moving platform with respect to the fixed platform for a given set {qi,q¯i} of generalized coordinates. It is evident that this analysis is equivalent to compute the coordinates of points Ci = (Xi, Yi, Zi). To this end, based on the lower links of the double legs of the robot, six simple closure equations may be written as (1)(Bi-Ai)·(Bi-Ai)=ei2 and (2)(Bi-A¯i)·(Bi-A¯i)=q¯i2 where the dot (·) denotes the usual inner product of three-dimensional vectorial algebra. Hereafter coefficients, which are marked as *~, are not provided in the contribution in order to not distract the attention of the reader with long expressions. After, Ci may be expressed as (6)Ci=Ai+qi(Bi-Ai)/ei Furthermore, for the parameters dij, there are three closure equations given by (7)(Ci-Cj )·(Ci-Cj )=dij 2 i,j=1,2,3 mod (3) The substitution of equation (6) into expression (7) leads to a non-linear system of three equations in the unknowns Z1, Z2, and Z3 given by (8)AijZi 2Zj 2+BijZi 2Zj+CijZiZj 2+DijZi 2+EijZj 2 +FijZiZj+GijZi+HijZj+Iij=0 i,j=1,2,3 mod (3) In what follows the non-linear system of equation (8) is solved by means of the Sylvester's dialytic method of elimination.

Later on, the remaining coordinates of the points Bi are computed by resorting to equations (3) and (5). Finally, once the coordinates of points Bi are computed, the coordinates of points Ci are calculated by means of equation (6).

On the other hand, the IDA consists of finding the generalized coordinates of the robot, given the pose of the moving platform with respect to the fixed platform, in other words given the coordinates of the centers of the spherical joints. The IDA of the Stewart platform is straightforward and it is included here only for the sake of completeness. Indeed, given the coordinates of points Ci, the generalized coordinates qi are directly computed as (14)qi=(Ci-Ai)·(Ci-Ai) Furthermore, in order to compute the generalized coordinates q¯i consider that, according to equation (6), points Bi may be expressed as (15)Bi=eiCi/qi+Ai After, the generalized coordinates q¯i are obtained as (16)q¯i=(Bi-A¯i)·(Bi-A¯i)

Finally, it is worth to note how easy is to formulate the FDA of the Stewart platform due to the introduction of equation (6). Consider for instance that the FDA of the Gough platform is governed by a set of seven quadratic equations.13 Certainly, while the FDA of the general Gough platform is a formidable task does not allow for closed-form solutions, see for instance,13–21 the corresponding analysis for the Stewart platform requires of only few paragraphs yielding nearly closed-form solutions due to its decoupled topology.

sec.title: Singularity analysis
sec.p: The I/O equation of velocity is the mean employed to elucidate the singularities of the Stewart platform. Hence, matrices A and B, see expression (23), are studied in order to approach the singularity analysis of the robot under study. The Stewart platform is at a singular configuration when: (i) matrix A is singular, named direct singularity, (ii) matrix B is singular, named inverse singularity, and (iii) matrices A and B are both singular, named combined singularity.

sec.title: Direct singularity
sec.p: Taking into account that A = JT Δ, then matrix A becomes singular when the elements of matrix J=[5$61 5$62 5$63 $1 $2 $3] are linearly dependent, e.g. when the directions of the screws are coplanar, in other words when the double legs are coplanar. In general, at a direct singularity, the manipulator loses degrees of freedom, more specifically if the double legs are coplanar, then the Stewart platform loses three of its six-degrees-of-freedom. Hence, there are two main possibilities to be considered: (i) the actuators q¯i assume the role of passive kinematic pairs and depend of the actuators qi (ii) the actuators qi assume the role of passive kinematic pairs and depend of the actuators q¯i. The first possibility implies that the Stewart platform with coplanar double legs is kinematically equivalent to the 3-RPR three-degrees-of-freedom planar parallel manipulator. The singularity analysis of non-redundant planar parallel manipulators was successfully achieved by Bonev et al.,26 a fine piece of work, by applying the theory of screws, and therefore this possibility is not included in the contribution. On the other hand, with the purpose to determine the direct singularity loci of the second possibility, consider a sub-matrix J¯=[5$61 5$62 5$63]. Then, the direct loci singularity is expressed as det(J¯)=0 where the screws of J¯ are computed considering that Bi = (Xi, 0, Zi). Hence, solving equations (2) and (3), it follows that (31)Xi=a~i+b~iq¯i 2+c~iZi, Zi=d~i+e~iq¯i 2+f~i+g~iq¯i 2+h~iq¯i 4 Furthermore, taking into account that in Plücker coordinates 5$6i=[5s∧i 6Ai×5s∧i 6] where 5s∧i 6=(Bi-Ai)/ei. Then, after removing rows with zero values, the screws of J¯ are given by (32)5$6i=[i~i+j~iq¯i 2+k~i+l~iq¯i 2+m~iq¯i 4n~i+p~iq¯i 2+q~i+r~iq¯i 2+s~iq¯i 4t~i+u~iq¯i 2+v~i+w~iq¯i 2+x~iq¯i 4] After, the computation of the determinant of J¯ is straightforward. Furthermore, as proved by Stewart, another direct singularity occurs when the primal parts of the screws of J¯ are along the Y-axis which implies that 5$6i=[1 -azi axi]T. The computation of the direct singularity loci in accordance with this possibility is a trivial endeavor.

sec.title: Inverse singularity
sec.p: Matrix B is singular, if and only if det(B) = 0. Hence, the condition of inverse singularity of the Stewart platform is given by (33){$p1;$1} {$p2;$2} {$p3;$3}=0 The computation of any of the Klein forms thereof equation (33) leads to (34){2$¯i 3-{1$2i;2$¯i 3}{1$2i;3$¯i 4}3$¯i 4;$i}=0 Thus, an inverse singularity occurs when in a double leg the corresponding points Ai, Āi, and Bi are located in the same line, in other words an inverse singularity occurs only when a double leg of the Stewart platform is fully extended or folded.

sec.title: Combined singularity
sec.p: If the lines 5$61, 5$62, and 5$63 are coplanar, then det(A) = 0. Furthermore, if in a double leg the points Ai, Āi, and Bi are aligned, then det(B) = 0. This is called a combined singularity.

Finally, concerned with singular configurations, it is worth to note that compared with the Gough platform, see for instance,27–30 the Stewart platform has fewer singularities due to its decoupled topology.

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p: In order to demonstrate the application of the method of kinematic analysis proposed in the contribution, in this section, two numerical examples are provided.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In 1966, one of the most celebrated theoretical contributions concerned with the development of flight simulators was published in the proceedings of the (British) IMechE.1 An unusual number of communications which were promptly published in the same proceedings followed Stewart's paper. Such communications focused on the originality and possible applications of the new flight simulator as well as the mathematical methods employed by Stewart to approach the singularity analysis of the mechanism. The most disappointed opinion appeared when Gough noted that the same mechanical system had been devised by he and his colleagues at Dunlop Rubber Co., Birmingham, UK, in 1947 finishing with the construction of a prototype in 1955. The seminal contributions of Gough3,4 and Stewart1 represent the beginning of an intensive, creative, and fruitful research field devoted to the development of robot manipulators based on parallel kinematic structures. However, although those pioneering contributions have an honorable status in the literature of modern kinematics, as it is exposed by Fichter et al.5 and Bonev,6 it seems that the credits of such contributions are not properly attributed and could be recorded in the near future. In this study, the position, velocity, acceleration, and singularity analyses of the original Stewart platform are addressed in order to show that the Stewart and Gough platforms are parallel manipulators possessing quite different kinematic properties.

The FDA, a rather complicated task for most parallel manipulators, of the Stewart platform developed in this contribution is based on simple closure equations formulated according to the nominal positions of the revolute joints connecting the primary and secondary limbs of the robot. As far as the author is aware, expressions (6) have not been considered in previous works. By applying the Sylvester's dialytic method of elimination, all the solutions of the FDA of the Stewart platform steam from the roots of a 16th-order univariate polynomial equation. It is worthwhile to emphasize that the FDA of the Gough platform is a formidable task where all the solutions steam from the roots of a 40th-order univariate polynomial equation, for details, the reader is referred to references.16–19 Thus, a comparison concerned with the complexity of the FDA between the Stewart and Gough platforms is straightforward. On the other hand, the I/O equations of velocity and acceleration of the Stewart platform are obtained systematically by resorting to reciprocal-screw theory. Furthermore, the singularities of the robot are explained by studying the matrices associated to the I/O equation of velocity. These results agree with the conclusions reported by Stewart dealing with the so-called instability configurations of the mechanism. By employing simple concepts of linear algebra and screw theory, the conditions of singularity for the Stewart platform are easily established. As it was expected, due to the decoupled topology of the Stewart platform, the singularity analysis indicate that the illness regions of the Stewart platform are considerably smaller than those reported for the Gough platform, see for instance.27–30 In order to show the application of the method of kinematic analysis, numerical examples were included in the contribution. These examples were successfully verified with the aid of special software like ADAMS©.

Finally, the experience gained with the contribution allows to affirm that unlike the tire testing machine of Gough, the flight simulator of Stewart is a partially decoupled robot, and therefore its kinematic analyses are simpler than the required for the Gough platform.
